section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards, drawing supplies, index cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Vincent Paints His House. We noticed the letters T, A, and M as we read.
This is uppercase T and this is lowercase t. The letter T makes the /t/ sound you hear in tiger and turtle.
This is uppercase A and lowercase a. The letter a makes the /a/ sound you hear in apple and in ant.
This is uppercase M and lowercase m. The letter M stands for the /m/ sound you hear in milk and mitten.
Today we’ll match the pictures on the Activity Cards with the beginning letters Tt, Aa, or Mm.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the cards on the table with the pictures facing downward. Place the Alphabet Cards for Tt, Aa, and Mm on the table.
Ask Invite a child to turn over a card and say the picture name. Help them to blend the initial onset and rime to say the word. Then have them match the card with the appropriate Alphabet Card.
Repeat Continue with other children until all of the cards are matched. Then work together and make sure all the picture cards in the group match the Alphabet Card.
Practice Writing Letters Tt, Aa, and Mm Help children practice writing uppercase and lowercase Tt, Aa, and Mm. Provide drawing supplies.
Turn the cards face up and say a picture name. Ask children to repeat it with you, emphasizing the initial sound. Then help them find the matching Alphabet Card.
Ask children to make several different picture cards that they can add to the game. Provide small index cards and markers or crayons.

When presenting phonemic awareness activities, we often refer to sounds at the beginning, middle, or end of a word. Make sure you use consistent vocabulary during these activities. Children can easily be confused if you use different sequence words, such as “first” instead of “beginning.”
Exaggerate the movement of your mouth as you say beginning sounds. Be aware of your tongue and lip positions. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they say beginning sounds.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65184-3. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials modeling clay

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread the story Vincent Paints His House. We talked about how he set a goal and made plans to paint his house a different color.
When we make a plan, we begin by thinking about what we want to do, or our goal. Then we think about the steps that will help us reach our goal.
In this activity, we’re going to create our own houses just like Vincent. We’re going to talk about the steps we need to take to reach our goal of building our houses.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Ask children to think about what the first step might be in reaching their goal of building a house. Once we have our modeling clay, what’s the first thing we should do?
Model Model thinking and choosing the color of your house. First, I’m going to decide which color my house will be.
Set Up Ask children to think about which color they’d like to use to “paint” their house. Provide each child modeling clay.
Model Model building the base of a house before children build.
Repeat Model adding a roof to the house before children add one.

Talk About Planning Once the houses are complete, invite children to reflect on the activity. What was the goal we set? How did we make plans to reach our goal? What were the steps we took? Why did you decide on the colors you did?

Provide three or four colors for children to choose from in order to narrow children’s choices and lessen decision-making anxiety. Reassure children that their houses do not need to look exactly like yours but provide support as necessary.
Allow children to build any sort of building of their choosing and experiment with different colors. Ask children to write or dictate the steps for building and “painting” their houses.
Help multilingual learners identify the English names for colors. Take time, as needed, to review colors such as red, orange, yellow, green, blue, purple, black, and brown.
Help children develop fine motor skills by providing support as they mold their houses out of modeling clay. This activity will help children develop the small muscles of the hands.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65184-3. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Toucan Can Talk, The Attic, My Mess, drawing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we reread Vincent Paints His House, we noticed the letter t in titanium, a in amber, and m in manganese.
Today we’re going to read Toucan Can Talk, The Attic, and My Mess and create stories together with the words that we see at the book of each book.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Discuss Write down and read aloud the words on the back cover of Toucan Can Talk. Provide children with drawing supplies. Let’s create a new story together about the words that start with t .
Write Invite children to write and draw the story on their paper as you create your story together.
Repeat Continue this activity with The Attic and words that start with a and My Mess and words that start with m.

Share Stories and Practice Writing Tt, Aa, and Mm Invite children to share their stories with the group. Then encourage children to practice writing the letters Tt, Aa, and Mm. What was your favorite story we wrote today? What new letter would you like to write a story about?

Focus on just one letter instead of all three and guide children through each step of creating a story and involving words that begin with the chosen letter. Reread the Alphabet Book and have children identify the beginning letter of each specified word.

Challenge children to create a story about a new letter of their choice. Invite children to list words that begin with their chosen letter and create a story using those words. Challenge the group to each select a different letter.
Be aware that the Spanish phoneme /t/ is softer than the English phoneme /t/. Take time, as needed, to review the English phonemes /t/, /ă/, /ā/, and /m/ and have children say the sounds with you.

Be aware when children seem to be emotionally or academically “overloaded” during small-group activities. Take a moment for children to stretch and move to help them find control and attend to the activity.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65184-3. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials drawing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read A Horse, of Course, we talked about different ways that people express themselves. Drawing is one way that people show ideas and feelings.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity Explain that today children will express themselves by making up a new kind of animal. They will create a drawing to show what the animal looks like.

Model Explain the activity by modeling a drawing of an imaginary animal. Discuss what you are doing, such as, My animal has the face of a cat. I’ll draw that. But it has a long body and long legs. It can run really fast! And my animal has stripes, so I’ll draw that, too.
Ask Ask children to draw and color their imaginary animals. The animal can have any types of features, and can be realistic or fanciful.

Talk About It After the drawings are complete, invite children to describe their animals. Encourage others to ask questions, such as: Does your animal fly? What does it eat? Encourage children to use conversational etiquette, such as taking turns to talk, making eye contact, and using an appropriate tone of voice.
Support children by providing one facet of the animal, such as the face of a cat or the tale of a whale. Allow children to build off of the initial idea in order to create their animal.
Invite children to name their animal and create a habitat for it. Ask questions to stimulate their thinking, such as where the animal lives and whether it likes hot or cold weather.
Help multilingual learners identify the English names for common animal parts such as face, body, legs, wings, fins, fur, tail, and beak.

Encourage children to use their senses as they create animals. Help them think about how the animals look, feel, sound, and smell. Point out that including some of these ideas will make their animals come alive! Point out that using their senses can be an important part of creativity.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65184-3. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
